div.sent: No country in the world is solely independent.
Every country has to depend on others in some respect.
Every country wants to fulfil the demand of its own people as well as to make itself developed and rich.
And for this it has to take help and cooperation from a neighbouring country or others.
Keeping this objective of mutual cooperation in view, many organizations and alliances have developed in the world.
Such three organizations formed by the countries of south Asia are SAARC, ASEAN and BIMSTEC.
Let's now briefly discuss these three regional organizations.
SARC: SAARC was formed in 1985 with seven south Asian countries namely Bangladesh, India, Pakistan, Nepal, Bhutan, Sri Lanka and the Maldives.
The full name of the organization is South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation.
In the pact, cooperation in 9 sectors were mentioned such as, agriculture, weather, rural development, science, communication, education, environment and technical.
Later in 2005, Afghanistan became a member of SAARC.
The present members of SAARC are eight.
The Head Quarters of the organization is at Kathmandu in Nepal.
The main objectives of the organization are to solve the regional problems through mutual cooperation and the development of SAARC countries.
Besides, the leaders of these seven countries agreed on the development through mutual cooperation in terrorism, HIV/AIDS, commerce investment, education and environment.
It is a regional cooperation organization of south Asian countries.
The full name of the organisation is Association of South Asian Nations.
This cooperation organisation consists of ten countries.
They are Indonesia, Singapore, Philippines, Malaysia, Thailand, Brunei, Vietnam, Myanmar, Cambodia and Laos.
The Head Quarter of ASEAN is in Indonesian capital Jakarta.
The main objective of the association is mutual cooperation among members in the development of social, economic, cultural, scientific and technical fields.
The full name of BIMSTEC is Bay of Bengal Initiative for Multi Sector Technical and Economic Cooperation.
The member countries are Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, Thailand, Myanmar, Nepal and Bhutan.
At present the scope for cooperation among members has been extended.
Commerce, investment, technology, tourism, human resource development, agriculture, fisheries, transport and communication, medicine, textile, leather etc have been included in it.
